{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3756746,"name":"","username":"nstrike","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png","created_at":"2025-10-07T01:52:06.377Z","cooked":"

I have added Exponential Profiles to YAMS. Its still undergoing testing and I am waiting for it to be used on a real robot before I am confident enough to release the next version.

Here is my current example. You just have to generate the ExponentialProfile.Constraints via a static function in ExponentialProfilePIDController.

github.com/Yet-Another-Software-Suite/YAMS

examples/simple_robot/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/ElevatorSubsystem.java

master 

      
    
          
  1.   private final SmartMotorControllerConfig motorConfig        = new SmartMotorControllerConfig(this)
    2. 
          
  2.       .withMechanismCircumference(Meters.of(Inches.of(0.25).in(Meters) * 22))
    3. 
          
  3.       .withClosedLoopController(new ExponentialProfilePIDController(30, 0, 0, ExponentialProfilePIDController
    4. 
          
  4.           .createElevatorConstraints(Volts.of(12),
    5. 
          
  5.                                      DCMotor.getNEO(1),
    6. 
          
  6.                                      Pounds.of(16),
    7. 
          
  7.                                      Meters.of(Inches.of(0.25).in(Meters) * 22).div(2 * Math.PI),
    8. 
          
  8.                                      new MechanismGearing(GearBox.fromReductionStages(3, 4)))))
    9. 
          
  9. //      .withClosedLoopController(4, 0, 0, MetersPerSecond.of(0.5), MetersPerSecondPerSecond.of(0.5))
    10. 
          
  10.       .withSoftLimit(Meters.of(0), Meters.of(2))
    11. 
          
  11.       .withGearing(gearing(gearbox(3, 4)))
    12. 
          
  12. //      .withExternalEncoder(armMotor.getAbsoluteEncoder())
    13. 
          
  13.       .withIdleMode(MotorMode.BRAKE)
    14. 
          
  14.       .withTelemetry("ElevatorMotor", TelemetryVerbosity.HIGH)
    15. 
          
  15. //      .withSpecificTelemetry("ElevatorMotor", motorTelemetryConfig)
    16. 
          
  16.       .withStatorCurrentLimit(Amps.of(40))
    17. 
          
  17. //      .withVoltageCompensation(Volts.of(12))
    18. 
          
  18.       .withMotorInverted(false)
    19. 
          
  19. //      .withClosedLoopRampRate(Seconds.of(0.25))
    20. 
          
  20. //      .withOpenLoopRampRate(Seconds.of(0.25))
    21.
This file has been truncated. show original

I dislike the redundancy in this design but for a complex feature that can be acceptable as the redundancy can be taken care of via Constants.

Does anyone know when you should use an exponential profile over Trapazoidal? Does anyone have decent examples of Exponential Profiles?

nstrike:

Does anyone know when you should use an exponential profile over Trapazoidal?

Exponential curves should be the default, imo, since it follows the real-world behavior of motor curves.

nstrike:

Meters.of(Inches.of(0.25).in(Meters) * 22).div(2 * Math.PI),

What does this dimension represent? Dividing by 2pi implies the 0.25"x22 measurement is the circumference of something with a ~0.875" radius, but why not just use the radius directly? I’m also not sure why you’re doing so many unit conversions here, it could be simplified down to use native inches

Inches.of(0.25).times(22).div(2 * Math.PI)

// or consolidate if the circumference measurement is important
Inches.of(0.25 * 22).div(2 * Math.PI)

And are the commented-out lines of code examples of something or just dead code?

SamCarlberg:

examples of something

They are examples of something. All of those features exist but aren’t needed for Elevators or something else.

SamCarlberg:

What does this dimension represent

This dimension represents the drum radius for LinearSystemId.createElevatorSystem

github.wpilib.org

LinearSystemId (WPILib API 2025.3.2)

declaration: package: edu.wpi.first.math.system.plant, class: LinearSystemId

i was doing the conversion because it shows where the number came from instead of a magic number.

SamCarlberg:

0.25"x22 measurement is the circumference of something

It is! Thats the chain size * sprocket teeth for chain driven elevator drum circumferences

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-10-07T02:52:24.219Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":117,"readers_count":116,"score":23.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":506930,"topic_slug":"exponential-profiles-in-mechanisms","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL & YASS Creator "},"post_url":"/t/exponential-profiles-in-mechanisms/506930/4","custom_user_title":"YAGSL & YASS Creator ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3756784,"name":"Sam Carlberg","username":"SamCarlberg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/samcarlberg/{size}/207684_2.png","created_at":"2025-10-07T03:01:09.364Z","cooked":"
nstrike:

They are examples of something. All of those features exist but aren’t needed for Elevators or something else.

Cool, can you document that? Otherwise it’s hard to know what your intent is just from reading the example code.

nstrike:

i was doing the conversion because it shows where the number came from instead of a magic number.

Gotcha. That’s still magic numbers, just wrapped in measurement objects; I’d make those fields so they’re given descriptive names.

private final Distance chainPitch = Inches.of(0.25);
private final int toothCount = 22;
private final Distance circumference = chainPitch.times(toothCount);
private final Distance radius = circumference.div(2 * Math.PI);
